issues.description: The template's addGuestStudents method signature does not match the problem statement and the solution. The problem statement and UML specify addGuestStudents(int) (single int parameter) and the solution implements public void addGuestStudents(int). However, the template declares public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput) with an extra boolean parameter. This parameter mismatch will confuse students about the expected signature and prevent them from implementing the method that matches the exercise specification and the tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template method signature with the specification and solution by changing the template declaration to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... } If the boolean validateInput parameter was intended for internal validation, implement validation inside the single-parameter method (or provide an overload with clear documentation) so that the public API matches the problem statement and tests.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and tasks) specifies a method addGuestStudents(int): void (single int parameter). The solution implements public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) (single int parameter) which matches the UML. However, the template repository declares addGuestStudents with a different signature: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents, boolean validateInput). This extra boolean parameter in the template changes the expected method signature and the conceptual contract of the operation, creating a mismatch between problem statement, template, and solution. Students following the UML or the solution will expect a single-argument method and may be confused about which method to implement or how tests will call it.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template method signature with the UML and the solution by removing the extra boolean parameter. Change the template declaration to: public void addGuestStudents(int numberOfNewGuestStudents) { ... } Alternatively, if input validation via a boolean is intended pedagogically, update the problem statement (UML) and the solution to reflect the two-parameter signature and document the purpose of the boolean so students clearly understand the expected contract.
